title-group.article-title: Geometrically based metrics featuring area and shape for multidimensional wildland fire models

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering, New Mexico State University, Las Cruces, NM, USA

author-notes.corresp: Humberto Silva III, c/o Department of Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering, New Mexico State University, P.O. Box 30001/MSC 3450, Las Cruces, NM 88003-8001, USA. Email: hrsilva@nmsu.edu

abstract.p: There is, indeed, a shortage of methods to validate, verify, or simply show the performance of multidimensional wildland fire models under certain criteria. Many approaches are possible, but this study will undertake total shape and size of area burned as the metric criteria with such models. In particular, two area shape and size metrics are presented for application to a fire area simulator. Both metrics are then analyzed to show which one is better suited for predictions that have protruding fire fronts and overshoots. In addition, a numerical experiment is presented herein, which simply demonstrates how such metrics can be utilized to validate fire area simulators.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A recent review by Pastor et al.1 reveals that since World War II, a large number of wildland fire behavior models have been developed. Wildland fires affect nearly every country; hence, modeling efforts reflect a worldwide effort. The models listed by Pastor et al.1 fall into the empirical, semiempirical, and theoretical categories. Some models apply to surface spread only, while others apply to crown fires. For the latter category, there are both initiation and spread models available. Any model that is capable of providing a measurable prediction or simulation of at least one fire characteristic is a candidate for model validation. In particular, if the model can predict a fire perimeter, and requires one or more inputs, such as fuel and weather characteristics, then the metrics introduced in this article may be applied.

The ability to model wildland fire behavior is highly desirable. An obvious use for a model is the prediction of fire movement once a fire has begun. Decisions regarding how to allocate resources, if or when to order evacuations, and protection of firefighting personnel can all benefit from accurate fire prediction. A model for real-time use must be computable in a time short compared to significant spread of the fire. FARSITE2 is an example of such a computationally fast model.

Peterson et al.3 investigated the dependence of FARSITE perimeter predictions, as compared to the actual Simi Fire event. They considered fuel specification and mapping resolution, weather inputs, and FARSITE perimeter resolution. FARSITE models the fire perimeter as a polygon with fire propagating from each vertex as a wave front. The perimeter resolution has a strong effect on computational time, but a less clear impact on model accuracy.

There are published articles on wildland fire that consider the sensitivity of model outputs to inputs. In two recent articles,4,5 Rothermel’s model was chosen for analysis.6 In addition to this common feature, both articles consider the model output at a point. In neither article were the effects of uncertainty over time considered. In another article,2 FARSITE is applied to the 2003 Simi Fire that occurred in southern California. FARSITE is also based on the Rothermel model, and it models fire propagation as a spreading wave front. In contrast to the first two articles, Peterson et al.3 investigate the time integrated output in the form of the fire perimeter.

Bachmann and Allgöwer4 considered the main outputs: rate of fire spread (ROS (m s−1)), direction of maximum spread (SDR (°)), and effective wind speed (EFW (m s−1)). The authors note that fire line intensity, heat release per area, and flame length can be derived. Bachmann and Allgöwer chose to perform a first-order Taylor series analysis to assess the sensitivity of the outputs to inputs. The range of inputs was chosen from a 2.5 × 2.5 km2 site, and the variation over 25 × 25 m2 cells was assessed. As with the study by Salvador et al.,5 no time integrated effects were considered.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: The primary purpose of the work described herein is to investigate the time integrated effects of input parameter uncertainty on the geometrical extent of a fire and use this geometrical variation as a performance tool, which in the future could serve as criteria for model validation. Although possible, the current effort is not meant to expose the most important or influential input parameters. To do this, a method similar to Peterson et al.3 could be employed.

This article will present two area shape and size (of fire burn area) metrics which will serve as performance measuring tools for fire models and may also serve as a criterion for future validation of certain models. Specifically, we want to show which of the proposed metrics is better suited for simulations that exhibit “overshoots” of fire fronts.

A metric, which characterizes the shape and size of the fire after a specific burn time, is repeatedly determined for a range of input parameter values. Perturbations from a nominal fixed case for chosen parameters (wind speed, wind direction, high relative humidity) were employed to demonstrate the usage of the metric as a performance rating tool since multiple data from real fires are needed to make a true validation study. From the metric value distribution, it may be possible to make a statement about the accuracy of the underlying fire model, relative to the uncertainty of the input parameters. Although FARSITE was chosen for performance demonstrations, the authors make no statements about the validity of this software.

Models that rely on more detailed physics, such as FIRETEC,7,8 preclude their use as real-time fire predictors due to computational requirements. A physics-based model is useful in post fire simulation, understanding the detailed interactions between fire and the environment, and studying what-if scenarios, such as thinning strategies. Nonetheless, as with the computationally faster semiempirical models, physics-based models can, in principal, be validated with the method described herein.

sec.title: Geometrically based metrics
sec.p: For wildland fires, there are many aspects that may be of interest. These include fire front intensity, local rate of spread, smoke production, spotting, and area burned. This last item is the focus of this study, which considers the region burned by a fire after a fixed period of time. With this metric, two shapes, each with fixed but different areas, will have different τ values depending on their degree of overlap. Perfect agreement between two shapes results in a metric value of zero. Although Peterson et al.3 used the Lee–Sallee metric in their work, it was originally developed to compare highly irregular shapes to basic shapes such as a circle, rectangle, or triangle. The metric proposed below was developed thinking specifically about wildland fires. To this end, accounting for how far one fire front was from another, as well as some shape detail, was felt important.

sec.title: FARSITE implementation
sec.p: The public domain software FARSITE is based on Rothermel’s semiempirical model and was chosen to demonstrate the utility of the previous metrics. There were two primary reasons for this choice. The first is that the calculations were very fast. For this study, a “12-h” burn required only a few seconds to complete on a 2.66 GHz PC. The second reason is that the predicted fire perimeter can be output as the x–y vertices of a polygon (it is a fire area simulation). The resolution of the polygon may be set by the user. The file with the polygon vertices was called from a quasi object-oriented (structure based) MATLAB program that then evaluated all the metrics.

sec.title: Demonstrative numerical experiment
sec.p: A horizontal rectangular region, 3240 × 3120 m2, was divided into eight fuel regions using seven Anderson fuel types12 (Table 1). The properties of these fuel types are part of the FARSITE database. A schematic diagram of the fuel layout is shown in Figure 2. The rectangular nature of the fuel regions was chosen for convenience only. The fire origin for all runs is shown as the black dot near the lower center of Figure 3.

caption.p: Schematic diagram showing the various fuel types and regions used for all FARSITE runs.

Numbers in each region refer to the Anderson fuel types (see Table 1). The black dot marks the origin of the fire. The inner solid curve represents the base case burn: 5 mile/h wind speed from a direction of 180°. The dashed curve represents the case for a 7 mile/h wind speed from a direction of 160°. For both cases, the high humidity limit was 60% relative humidity.
Run time of Lee–Sallee metric for all the cases within the numerical setup.

sec.p: FARSITE allows several parameters to be varied. For this study, the following three parameters were chosen: wind speed, wind direction, and high humidity limit. For both wind speed and wind direction, uniform probability distribution functions were elected to represent the uncertainty in these parameters. The wind speed ranged from 2 to 8 mile/h. The wind direction ranged from 165° to 195°. The high humidity limit was taken at three values: 50%, 60%, and 70% relative humidity. Each humidity value was given an equal probability of 1/3 (uniform probability distribution). For each run, the chosen input values were held constant for the “12-h” burn time. FARSITE does allow for changing these values over time though. The perimeter resolution was set at 120 m. As mentioned previously, this article is meant to introduce a simple performance methodology and the metrics only and is not meant as a validation test of FARSITE itself. Thus, these constraints were not chosen for any other reason than to demonstrate to the reader how one could use the metrics in this mock setup to use as a future validation tool for FARSITE. If real burn data existed, we would take the same approach, which is to have the uncertainty parameters perturbed (while acquiring their true respective probability density functions (pdfs)) and then test these “perturbations” or “predictions” with the “real” or “base” fire via the metric of choice for a particular study.

A total of 337 (7 × 16 × 3 + 1) runs were made. It was found that the results were not very sensitive to wind direction, so steps sizes of 2° were taken rather than 1°. The plus one run was for the base case, which was calculated for a 5 mile/h wind, 180° wind direction (from bottom to top of Figure 3), and high humidity limit of 60% relative humidity which serves as the nominal case. FARSITE interpolates over the day to determine current ambient temperature and humidity. For all the runs, high humidity occurred at 05:00 h and low humidity at 15:00 h. Fires started at midnight. As a reminder for later discussion, the base case is considered the modeler’s best estimate since we did not have real fire data.

A comment needs to be made about measuring the actual fire perimeter. One method for doing this is to take an aerial photograph of the burned area after a known elapsed time. The perimeter of the burned region could then be “traced” with a digitizer. The authors have done this with a digital photograph imported into MATLAB to demonstrate its feasibility and to determine likely levels of digitizing uncertainty. In general, different users would get somewhat different values for the polygon vertices. These differences would constitute measurement error.

sec.title: Optimal metric results
sec.p: Now, we need to consider what would be important to the user of such validation metrics since this article is really a comparison and evaluation of the metrics proposed. First, accuracy in capturing the ability of FARSITE to predict a fire scenario is most important. Second, efficiency of the metric or the metric run time is also important. These are two recurring attributes with almost any software or supplemental performance software.

We will examine the total run time of all the metrics first and then introduce a procedure for verifying the metric that optimally captures the true performance for FARSITE to model “overshoots.”Figure 3 illustrates that the Lee–Sallee metric take less than 10 s to run all 337 cases. Figure 4 shows that we start to have efficiency issues when our side length (dA) goes below 10 pixels as shown. Table 2 illustrates the percent error from a side length of 1 pixel and their respective time of completion for all the cases and the average run time for a single run. It is revealed that there is no real gain in accuracy below a side length of 50 pixels (>99% accuracy), so we will set all future analysis with the Silva–Leslie metric to this standard side length value. Moreover, with our side length of the Silva–Leslie metric set to 50 pixels, we really do not gain anything from a time perspective when using any of the metrics and thus time efficiency is not a real issue with any of the metrics proposed.

sec.p: Moving on, we now need to analyze these metrics and prove which one captures best the ability of FARSITE to predict the area and shaped burned of a real fire scenario for fire protrusions. A way to do this is by forcing “overshoots” or “protrusions” of a fire perimeter. The following subexperiment is an exercise to easily verify the optimal metric (metric that better captures the prediction capabilities of FARSITE for handling fire protrusions). First, we take the base case and move it to the left in space so the y vertices of the base case are fixed and the x vertices are shifted to the left in increments of 10%. The way to do this is to get the maximum x vertex and subtract the minimum x vertex and then divide by 10. This value (previous sentence) should be added every time you x-offset the base case. Then, we evaluate both metrics for this sub-setup as demonstrated in Figure 5. Second, we take the 180°, 2 mile/h, 60% relative humidity polygon and perturbed this case with respect to the wind speed. So, we will have seven windspeed-offsets in this sub-setup because we have seven wind speeds (2–8 mile/h). Then, we evaluate both metrics for this sub-setup as demonstrated in Figure 6. We know that the metric values in both of these sub-setups will correlate to each other with some unknown proportionality because they are both being pushed in the negative x direction. Next, we need to distinguish which metric is optimal for this study; we simply calculate the correlation coefficient and see which metric has the highest correlation (Table 3). sec.p: Now that we have shown what the optimal metric is for this study, we will analyze this metric with all 337 cases in cohesion with the base case (initial demonstration to illustrate a simple statistical procedure for future validation). Figure 8 shows the normalized value distribution for the 337 cases. Notice that the best fit curve is shaped like a bell around the nominal case and that 95% of the metric values lie between 0 and 0.7. Remember, we forced the setup to have uniform perturbations from the nominal case. This was done purposely to easily demonstrate usage of this metric with FARSITE for fire area burned. It is important to note that the methodology described is not intended to be universal.

caption.p: Histogram of Silva–Leslie metric with respect to the normalized probability of its values where the dashed vertical line is the 95% cumulative probability.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A geometrically based metric (Silva–Leslie) suitable for future statistical validation of wildland fire models has been introduced. The metric reflects the entire history of the fire up to time t. The probability distribution of the metric based on the uncertainty of the relevant input parameters, in conjunction with the perimeter measurement from an actual fire, can be used to assess the model performance rating for its total area burned and could be further developed to show if the model is statistically valid or not when ample real fire data become more readily available. The input parameter uncertainty of a model is crucial for the method introduced in this article because the perturbations from the uncertainty range are needed to have an acceptable sample to actually rate the performance of the model. Unrealistically large uncertainty limits may permit even a bad model to be accepted, while overly narrow estimates of the uncertainty for the same parameters may result in the rejection of a model that would have good utility if used properly. These indeed are flaws of any metric described in this article since they are scalar valued and need to be repeated several times to produce a large data set. However, even though the procedure to show the burned area performance rating of a fire model can be involved, both metrics described herein have a strong correlation in determining the ability of FARSITE to accurately predict a real fire case.10 This might be because the correlation utility deals with total area shape and size but still this observation cannot negate the fact that the ability to predict total area burned is indeed one factor to validate a model and some applications may only call for such geometrical features to be evaluated. For example, the Silva–Leslie metric may possibly unfold the validity of a fire area simulator/model for a particular burn situation (protruding fire fronts) which can then help fire fighters establish burn perimeter criterion (without actually calling for a real fire) with newfound confidence in the model via the metric. In conclusion, future work of this optimal metric is to replace the base case described in the numerical experiment with real fire data, obtain details of the uncertainty parameters and perturb the values with the appropriate pdfs and/or joint pdfs, and then generate a large enough prediction polygon sample to perform a statistical validation for numerous burn scenarios.

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Humberto Silva III earned his PhD in 2009 at Arizona State University in Aerospace Engineering with an emphasis in Computational Mathematics and Heat Transfer after receiving graduate degrees in both Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering and an undergraduate degree in Engineering Physics. Upon graduation he held a post-doc at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory then continued on to Raytheon Missile Systems as a Software and Systems Engineering. Currently, he is at Sandia National Laboratories working as a Thermal Numerical Analyst and Modeler.

Ian H Leslie earned his PhD in 1984 at Stanford University in Mechanical Engineering after conducting research in pulverized coal combustion. That same year he joined the Mechanical Engineering Department at New Mexico State University where he is today. Since then he has conducted research, directed graduate students, and published in combustion, CFD, validation, and aeronautics. He has taught a wide variety of courses at both the undergraduate and graduate level. On January 1, 2011 he was appointed associated department head of the Mechanical & Aerospace Department and on August 1, 2011 became interim department head.
